Package com.shortnweb.sally

Class ShellProcessor

java.lang.Object
com.shortnweb.sally.ShellProcessor
All Implemented Interfaces:
Runnable
public class ShellProcessor extends Object implements Runnable
Handles the input and output necessary to operate a complete shell application.

This class handles all input processing and logic needed for user interaction with a list of ShellVerbs. The primary value needed in any use of this class is the verbMap which stores a list of defined verb constructors and links them to the string value the user must enter to reference them. All output and input will be handled by System.in and System.out, the location these print and read from can be overwritten in the Main class.

The recommended use of this class is to create a new instance assigned to a variable, then utilize that variable to map the needed Strings to the accepted ShellVerbs, and finally call the run method. The program will loop within the run method until the user enters in an exit command.

When adding accepted verbs to the processor, note that "help" and "exit" are not allowed to be used as they are reserved for the processor. The built-in "help" verb will display the help field assigned to the processor, or to whatever verb is typed after it, separated by a space. The built-in "exit" verb is entered when users want to close out of the shell interface. Once this is entered the processors run method will stop executing, and the application will move on to whatever code comes after that call.

The shell interface looks very similar to any standard Unix terminal. The user will be greeted by this prompt: #: That prompt can be modified by specifying a name value for the processor, but this is not required. Here is an example of how a typical command will look as entered into the shell interface:

#: verb -bv 10 --text "Here is some text with spaces" -t text_no_spaces

Notice the structure of the above command. First is entered the specified call value for the desired verb (the key specified in the verbMap). Each argument afterward is separated by a space. There are two ways of specifying options when calling a verb. The first is with a single -. This short notation only needs a single character to locate the desired option, and one or multiple options can be specified at once. When multiple options are used, it is best to keep those at the beginning to only boolean options, and if desired end the statement with a single option accepting a value.

Alternatively, you can specify options with a double --. This long notation will search for an exact match to one option linked to that entire string. When entering a String as text, there are several options. For entries without spaces in them, you can simply type in the full value and it will be accepted. If you need to add spaces, you can surround the value in either double " or single ' quotes. If you need to enter one of those symbols in part of the value, escape the character by placing a \ in front of it.

    • getVerbMap

      Returns:
      unmodifiableMap copied from the verbMap.

    • setVerbMap

      public void setVerbMap(Map<String,Supplier<? extends ShellVerb>> verbMap)
      Sets a new value for the verbMap field.
      Parameters:
      verbMap - Map linking String keys to Supplier values. Supplier functions must return an object that extends the ShellVerb class.

    • addVerb

      public ShellProcessor addVerb(String key, Supplier<? extends ShellVerb> value)
      Adds a new key - value pairing to the verbMap. Note that the terms "help" and "exit" are reserved by the processor.
      Parameters:
      key - String value that the user will enter as a command.
      value - Supplier method that returns a new instance of a ShellVerb.
      Returns:
      ShellProcessor reference to this object, used to chain calls to this method.

    • run

      public void run()
      Starts the shell application running and handles all user input.

      This method will loop indefinitely until the user enters in the "exit" command.

      This method will print and read input using System.in and System.out

      Specified by:
      run in interface Runnable
